SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231} per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136} (£1.8a), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Mi- nimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria. London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. E.C.

DES MILLIERS D’ANNEES ne comptent pour rien dans Ies pays orientaux. Ce qui corapte pour beaucoup, e’est le moyen de gudrir la scrofule, Tan^mie ou tons semblables troubles du sang qui indiquent un etat d'affaiblissement de l'organisme. Mais il est aujourd’hui sur terre un remade k toutes ces affections: LtMULSION SCOTT Elle guerit et fait disparaitre la maladie tout comme le soleil dissipe les vapeurs miasmatiques. LtMULSION SCOTT chasse cette maladie qui guettait k votre porte. LtMULSION SCOTT uarqui de F.brique. sauvera 1? vie de vos enfants quand leur sang •era appauvri. En vente chez tous les pharmaciens et droguistes.

THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. the value of their lands that they sell at a price which justifies the shares of the pur- chasing company at once being doubled in value. That good solid business is possible we do not doubt, but public duty compels as to sound & note of serious warning against too much discounting of the future. To dis- count in this way is simply to buy money, and the unexpected which proverbially happens may be a windfall, bat is mire likely to prove being "left to hold the baby.”

FRIDAY MAY 19, 1905. MANCHURIA. COMPANIES AND SPECULATION. In view of the mass of new companies which have been already totaled in Egypt, and which i ire still appearing on tho horizon, one wel- comes any publication which takes a sane view of the situation, and is based on common j tense. The first number of ‘‘La Revue Inter- nationale d'Egypte” has just appeared, and it: contains an article by M. Leopold Jullien on ; “La Situation Economique de l’Egypte,” which • is well worth perusal. M. Ju'.liea points out that formerly there wore few company shares! dealt in on the Bourses of Alexandria and i Cairo, as shares were held by large capitalists, j and only small lots were available for the public; but all that is now in god, and the public are entering on share speculation in any company which is presented. It says though wealth of the public aid the bushel spirit of eater- j prise would be a matter of congratulation if the situation were normal, but, hi add*, this infatuation of the public is not normal and tho position of the share market is becoming more dangerous. In this we omit. The rashing up of new companies to a premium before they have begun operations is quite without justification on any solid business grounds, and equally arousing is the fall, after a week or two, when some other company ; has appeared, of the same shares to a discount. The fellah buys land and borrows money and all Egypt lives on him. If Europeans have acquired wealth in Egypt, tho fellah is the basis of it all. Railways, ports, import and export houses are all for the fellah, fur there are no industries in the country. Truly the Egyptian Atlas has a heavy load on his back : a land tax of £4,750,000, interest on 30 millions private indebtedness, say £2,250,000, and rout on 6,000,000 feddans, say £18,000,000. The new companies have two foots stated above, "the fellah buys land and borrows m mey”—an 1 subiidiary to that people living on him need houses. There are three geographical words: Egypt, Nile, Delta; four financial words, Land, Bank, Trust, Investment. All that is needed is a clean sheet of paper and a fluent pen, and perhaps a little historical knowledge of what other companies did which were established long ago under different conditions. With this stock-in-trade a proipectus is easily pre pared, no originality is needed. An infatnatod public apply for shares, not because they wish sound investment, but to get shares of goo<i speculative character. M. Jullien restates u good many facts which have already been eet forth by other authorities, and they all go to prove the soundness of laud values in Urn* but as he points out, it is difficult to proprietors know 19 little of

RAILWAY GAUGE CHANGED. Thursday, May 18. The Japateto have completed tho changing of the gauge of the railway to Tiding. Supply trains are now running from the Sontb. They are also rapidly pushing construction north- ward, replacing destroyed bridges. (Reuter.)

PIRACY ON CANTON RIVER. REPRESENTATIONS OP BRITISH GOVERNMENT. London, May 18. Hot; sb or Commons.—Lord Percy said that Sir B. Satow has been instructed to com- municate with the Chinese Government in reference to the recrudesoence of piracy on the Canton river, (Rtuter.)

KING ALFONSO. HIS FORTHCOMING MARRIAGE. Madrid, May 18. King Alfonso, replying to the congratulations of the Senate on the occasion of his birthday, referred to his forthcoming marriage in con- nection with his visits to France and England. (Reuter.)
CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE. CONTINUED DISCUSSION IN CHAMBER. Paris, May 18. The Chamber of Deputies continuos to dis- ouss the law for the separation of the Churches from the State. (Haras.)
GRAND DUKE SERGIUS’S ASSASSIN EXECUTED. Moscow, May 18. The assassin of the Grand Duke Sergius has been executed. (Haras.)

ATLANTIC YACHT RACE. LIGHT WIND AT START. New York, May 18. The light wind at the start i f the race foi the Emperor William’s Cup favored schooner*, The “Valhalla" drifted across the line ai) hour behind the leader. The yachts disappear ed in the fop.
